user.biography:
🧠 Tales of an Autistic/ADHD human living in a neurotypical world.
🎙 @theautisticlifepodcast 
✨ More content on Patreon
💌 hello@theautistic.life

node.text:
A tiny tutorial on how to get you started with @tiimoapp + using my own routines as a starting point to create yours. Thank you so much to @tiimoapp for partnering with me for this! So many of you told me that you tried the app and loved it, but found it difficult to set up so hopefully this will be helpful! Also, a bit of me talking about my routines and how the app has helped me in my day-to-day life 💛
.
.
.
#autism #autistic #actuallyautistic #autisticadults #autisticteens #autismo #autista #mujeresautistas #aspie #aspiegirl #aspergers #aspergerssyndrome #aspergerslife #neurodiversity #neurodiverse #neurodivergent  #autismmoms #autismdads #autismparents #autismmomsrock #autisticselfadvocacy #autismpride #redinstead #autismrights

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by The Autistic Life on July 26, 2021 tagging @tiimoapp. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Autistic people often experience high levels of anxiety due to our executive functioning differences. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

node.text:
Can you relate? How do you cope with your executive-functioning-related anxiety? Thank you so much to @tiimoapp for this collaboration (and for existing and being so visual!). I was initially diagnosed with Generalized Anxiety Disorder, before my Autism and then ADHD diagnosis and for as long as I can remember I’ve experienced debilitating anxiety when it came to tasks, homework, projects. There’s something about multi-step activities and putting all of these cognitive skills into use at the same time that instantly throws my whole system off into a stress response. Then I learned they have a name and the actual challenges that come with them are called “executive dysfunction” and I was able to link my anxiety spikes with that. I’ve found that pausing to pay attention to my thoughts helps me A LOT, although sometimes I don’t manage to do it very well. I hope this helps in any way and if not, that's okay! It think when it comes to these things it’s very important that each of us finds a system that works for us individually. 
.
.
.
#autism #autistic #actuallyautistic #autisticadults #autisticteens #autismo #autista #mujeresautistas #aspie #aspiegirl #aspergers #aspergerssyndrome #aspergerslife #neurodiversity #neurodiverse #neurodivergent  #autismmoms #autismdads #autismparents #autismmomsrock #autisticselfadvocacy #autismpride #redinstead #autismrights

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by The Autistic Life on July 26, 2021 tagging @tiimoapp. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Autistic people often experience high levels of anxiety due to our executive functioning differences. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 26, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Due to our executive functioning profiles, we often struggle with attention, memory, organization, planning, emotional control, causing exhausting anxiety and putting us at a higher risk of experiencing meltdowns/shutdowns meltdowns frequently. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 26, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Anxiety in Autistic people can manifest as: .Sweating, muscle tension, neck pain, stomach aches, eye twitching, itchy skin; any of these increasing the likelihood of experiencing sensory overload and/or meltdowns. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 26, 2021. May be an image of text that says '•Being more fidgety than usual; leg bouncing, nail-biting, skin picking, chewing objects, more likely to engage in self-harming stimming. •Lower tolerance to frustration and experiencing frequent meltdowns. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 26, 2021. May be an image of text that says '.Situational mutism: being being unable to speak in certain high-stress situations that feel threatening. .Fear of new situations, canceling appointments, missing work or school, missing deadlines. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp noapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 26, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'As someone someone with Generalized Anxiety Disorder, slowing down helps me a lot. Much of my anxiety comes from feeling overwhelmed and then ruminating about it to the point of having panic attacks due to catastrophic thinking. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 26, 2021. May be an image of text that says '"Iwill fail at college and lose my scholarship," will get fired if miss the deadline," "I'm a failure. Pausing to listen to my thoughts helps me break the cycle of engaging in negative self-talk and spiking up my own anxiety levels. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo shared by The Autistic Life on July 26, 2021 tagging @tiimoapp. May be an image of text that says 'Tiimo (@tiimoapp) is a subscription-based app that helps you organize your day in a visual way and some of its some features really help me slow down when I'm anxious. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo shared by The Autistic Life on July 26, 2021 tagging @tiimoapp. May be an image of text that says 'How Tiimo helps me slow down: Scheduled eeae and check-ins throughout my day to avoid overworking myself. 17:00 Anxiety check in Take deep breath and be gentle to yourself 17:30 @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo shared by The Autistic Life on July 26, 2021 tagging @tiimoapp. May be a cartoon of text that says 'Creating a more gentle routine for days feel more anxious or I'm having a low executive function day. low executive functioning day 10 activities 15:59 h Created 2021-03-19 @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 08, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Autistic people may recur to analogies, metaphors, song lyrics, or pop-culture references to help us communicate our feelings. @theautisticlife'.

node.text:
Can you relate? Do you find it easier to communicate this way? The more I talk to Autistic people, the more I notice that we do this and I find it so so deeply wonderful, despite not always being well-received. I can understand it might be frustrating to be discussing something with someone and have them say “oh, it’s like in that Spider Man movie when…” or have them respond to a message with a song or a movie scene but these strategies are just as valid as actual words when they are used to help us communicate what we are feeling, as close as we can. If anything, they are better as the alternative is often not saying anything at all because we don’t know how to articulate how we feel and nothing seems to cut it. The point of this post is to bring light that, yes, sometimes it’s a “deficit in communication” from our end (I hate they put it that way) but other times it’s really just lack of willingness to listen “neurodivergently” from the other person. 
.
.
.
#autism #autistic #actuallyautistic #autisticadults #autisticteens #autismo #autista #mujeresautistas #aspie #aspiegirl #aspergers #aspergerssyndrome #aspergerslife #neurodiversity #neurodiverse #neurodivergent  #autismmoms #autismdads #autismparents #autismmomsrock #autisticselfadvocacy #autismpride #redinstead #autismrights

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Autistic Life on July 08, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Autistic people may recur to analogies, metaphors, song lyrics, or pop-culture references to help us communicate our feelings. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'As an Autistic person, being asked, "how are you feeling?" can be quite a stressful experience Sometimes I don't know how feel, sometimes I'm too aware of it but don't know how to articulate it. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 08, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'That's where analogies, metaphors and other people's words play a huge role in helping me explain what's happening. find it particularly usefu during arguments to get my point across and in therapy. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'For example, recently told my therapist that I often felt used by people, but not actually used, because that word was too big and broad It was the closest one I could find until I came up with this: @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says '"You know how you can lit up a candle with another candle? feel like I'm a lit candle and everyone comes near my flame to lit their candle up, but no one bothers checking if my flame is doing okay or lighting it up when I'm out." when @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Maybe it's hard to understand without context, but my therapist understood exactly what meant by that. We were able able to work on the actua issue instead of working on something that wasn't quite in alignment with how was feeling. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Please don't discard what we're saying if we use song lyrics or too many metaphors, or actual movie dialogues. We're trying to convey what we are feeling. Just because we borrow other people's words for it doesn't mean it's less valid. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 05, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Things that may be negatively impacting your daily functioning as an Autistic person. @theautisticlife'.

node.text:
Can you relate to any of this? Do these things affect your daily functioning? The last three weeks have been tough for me with college. I ended up reaching a point where I was not only experiencing Autistic burnout but was also completely and absolutely disconnected from everything. I just couldn't find anything that interested me. Life was too hard, and I had too many demands. After my semester was over, I took a week off from everything, and that's when things started to feel okay again. I began to feel like myself again. Then, I realized these things were severely impacting my functioning and my interest in life. What an absolute mess! Anyway, I hope any of this helps you pinpoint these things in your life and encourage you to make the proper changes (if possible) to make your life a bit easier.
.
.
.
#autism #autistic #actuallyautistic #autisticadults #autisticteens #autismo #autista #mujeresautistas #aspie #aspiegirl #aspergers #aspergerssyndrome #aspergerslife #neurodiversity #neurodiverse #neurodivergent #autismmoms #autismdads #autismparents #autismmomsrock #autisticselfadvocacy #autismpride #redinstead #autismrights

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Autistic Life on July 05, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Things that may be negatively impacting your daily functioning as an Autistic person. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Sensory input You might feel unexpectedly "off" or weird, tired or sleepy, "under the weather" like you have a headache, irritated or as if "something is missing due to sensory processing differences. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Sensory input This means that if we're feeling particularly "off," light might be too much, or not enough; sounds might be too much, or not enough; our sitting position might not be comfortable enough... so on and so forth with any of our senses @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Autistic burnout An intense degree of exhaustion can impact our ability to cope with setbacks, disagreements, illnesses- essentially, any stressful situation, making us more likely to experience sensory overloads, meltdowns, or shutdowns as a result. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Masking It adds another layer of pressure to everyday stressful situations. We are forced to go against our identity, wants, and needs to conform to social situations, normative expectations and/or to keep us safe. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Masking This means having to put conscious effort into specific tasks that are already draining for us as they are, potentially affecting aspects of us such as executive functioning skills or our ability to cope with uncomfortable sensory input. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Lack of emotional outlet No time or space for special interests and talents or not allowing yourself to do things that purposefully make you happy can result in a faster mental health decline since it means we have no emotional outlet to decompress from daily stress. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on July 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'It's essential for our Autistic well-being being to be aware of the moments these things start to affect our functioning, so we can take back control of the situation instead of making things unintentionally more difficult for ourselves. @theautisticlife'.
Autistic people are often perceived as condescending despite not aiming for that.

node.text:
Can you relate? Inspired by a classmate that continues to label me as condescending, coldhearted and… narcissistic ?? simply because when she asks a question I answer it and I sound like I’m lecturing her. I get we might hurt people’s feelings as a result of our ways of expressing but I also think people could make an effort to not take everything personally and when in doubt just ask to make sure it’s intentional or not? I don’t know. I’m tired.
.
.
.
#autism #autistic #actuallyautistic #autisticadults #autisticteens #autismo #autista #mujeresautistas #aspie #aspiegirl #aspergers #aspergerssyndrome #aspergerslife #neurodiversity #neurodiverse #neurodivergent  #autismmoms #autismdads #autismparents #autismmomsrock #autisticselfadvocacy #autismpride #redinstead #autismrights

node.accessibility_caption: Autistic people are often perceived as condescending despite not aiming for that.

Our tendency to be blunt and impulsive mean we don't always stop to check if our comments are socially appropriate or not. And if we do, we can't always tell if that's the case, so we take a guess, sometimes hurting
people as a result.

For many of us, reading social cues can be challenging so we don’t always pick those up and carry on talking as if nothing has happened, probably upsetting people even more and reinforcing the idea that we are intentionally trying to hurt them.
Our concepts of what’s socially appropriate are different in comparison to neurotypical people. For all I know, I’m being helpful and empathetic but the other person is feeling attacked and insulted.
This isn’t to say that we can’t be intentionally condescending; we can, but when in doubt, ask for clarification. Please don’t assume we want to hurt your feelings.

Consider the fact that many of us are already making a massive effort trying to communicate our thoughts. Our tone of voice, facial expressions and overall body language could not match what we are saying but it doesn’t mean we are trying to hurt you.

Photo by The Autistic Life on June 13, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'MORE CONTENT ON PATREON If you like my work and is accessobl for you to do so, please consider supporting my Patreon to get more resources and to show extra love! THE AUTISTIC LIFE 8 The Autistic Life is creating resources on autism, neurodivergence and mental health PATREON LINK IN BIO'.

Photo shared by The Autistic Life on June 08, 2021 tagging @fidgipop. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'The rumble stage: what happens before an Autistic meltdown @theautisticlife @fidgipop'.

node.text:
Can you relate? How does this look like for you? Thank you so so much to @fidgipop for collaborating with me, I appreciate it greatly!! The moments before a meltdown, the rumble stage, can be so so stressful on its own. Usually when I’m able to fight it off, all that built-up energy is still locked in so there’s always some sort of manifestation like more anxiety or sensory overload or difficulty in spoken conversations. It feels like my brain had a glitch and instead of rebooting, I did a couple of things to avoid that but it’s still not working as it should. I often need to sleep it off in order to regain control. Still, it can be helpful to figure out how your rumble stage looks like for you (or how it usually does) to pay attention to the signs and take a break before reaching the point of a meltdown.
.
.
.
#autism #autistic #actuallyautistic #autisticadults #autisticteens #autismo #autista #mujeresautistas #aspie #aspiegirl #aspergers #aspergerssyndrome #aspergerslife #neurodiversity #neurodiverse #neurodivergent  #autismmoms #autismdads #autismparents #autismmomsrock #autisticselfadvocacy #autismpride #redinstead #autismrights

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by The Autistic Life on June 08, 2021 tagging @fidgipop. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'The rumble stage: what happens before an Autistic meltdown @theautisticlife @fidgipop'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on June 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Many of us report experiencing messy breathing, tachycardia, dissociation, decreased verbal skills, nervousness, muscle tensing, and an overall feeling of unwellness. @theautisticlife @fidgipop'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on June 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'We might start to feel sensory and emotionally uncomfortable. For example, feeling like things are suddenly too bright, too loud, or deeply unsettling, annoying or painful. @theautisticlife @fidgipop'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on June 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'My anxiety spiking up is my first sign, almost as if an alarm goes off. I can feel things building up, my sensory processing gets jammed up, my breathing becomes messy, my spoken communication decreases, and there's an ntense "all over the place feeling. @theautisticlife @fidgipop'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on June 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Keep in mind that there there isn't a fixed list of signs to look for since our experiences before a meltdown will vary from person to person and from meltdown to meltdown. @theautisticlife @fidgipop'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on June 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'What can help you de-escalate? •Removing youself from the place to reduce stressors or seek sensory input. .Asking for a time-out to gather yourself, particularly helpful during arguments. Using sensory aids such as noise-canceling headphones, tinted glasses, weighted blanket. .Stimming to release built-up tension. @theautisticlife @fidgipop'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on June 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Carrying a stim toy with you can help you regain control of these overwhelming moments, especially when removing yourself from the situation is not possible. @theautisticlife @fidgipop'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on June 08, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says 'Some easily portable stim toys by FidgiPops: 사 Fidgicube Fidgispin Maze Cube Infinity Cube Colour Changing Squishy Glow Glwals @theautisticlife @fidgipop'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on June 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'FidgiPops is a small UK company that sells a great variety of stim toys for Neurodivergent people of all ages, and they have kindly collaborated with me to bring you this post. To learn more about them, you can follow @fidgipop or visit the store fidgipops.com @theautisticlife @fidgipop'.
Photo by The Autistic Life on May 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'As an Autistic person, vague vagu instructions are incredibly overwhelming. @theautisticlife'.

node.text:
Can you relate? I almost had a meltdown last week in class because the professor kept giving the same vague instructions for an assignment. I kept asking for clarification and they kept giving me the same information over and over again. It was so unnecesarily stressful. 
.
.
.
#autism #autistic #actuallyautistic #autisticadults #autisticteens #autismo #autista #mujeresautistas #aspie #aspiegirl #aspergers #aspergerssyndrome #aspergerslife #neurodiversity #neurodiverse #neurodivergent  #autismmoms #autismdads #autismparents #autismmomsrock #autisticselfadvocacy #autismpride #redinstead #autismrights

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Autistic Life on May 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'As an Autistic person, vague vagu instructions are incredibly overwhelming. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'My brain instantly thinks of a hundred ways to do the thing which means a hundred ways to get it wrong. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'It can be even more distressing when people refuse to give further explanations or continue to give the same answer. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'It isn't so much that I don't know how to do the thing, but rather, vague instructions increase the possibility of me getting stuck on deciding one way to do it because I can think of many. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Providing clear instructions or expectations can help reduce options and, as a result, we can start the task more easily. @theautisticlife'.
Photo by The Autistic Life on May 24, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Autistic people are more likely to experience sleep problems. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

node.text:
Can you relate? Honestly, I can’t remember a time not being tired. I’m always sleepy, to some degree or another. My sleep patterns have always been a mess, the quality of my sleep has always been awful, and for years I experienced insomnia and night anxiety. Medication for my generalized anxiety disorder and ADHD have really helped, but not entirely. Movement helps, but not always. The thing that has helped me the most is keeping up a sleep routine, although unfortunately sometimes it’s not possible to maintain because life happens. Thank you so much to Tiimo @tiimoapp for your collaboration and support, it means a lot to be able to write about this topic that is something that I’ve been researching lately precisely because I’m genuinely so tired of always being tired 😂
.
.
.
#autism #autistic #actuallyautistic #autisticadults #autisticteens #autismo #autista #mujeresautistas #aspie #aspiegirl #aspergers #aspergerssyndrome #aspergerslife #neurodiversity #neurodiverse #neurodivergent  #autismmoms #autismdads #autismparents #autismmomsrock #autisticselfadvocacy #autismpride #autismrights

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Autistic Life on May 24, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Autistic people are more likely to experience sleep problems. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 24, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'It might take us longer to fall asleep, we may wake up more frequently during the night and have less restorative sleep in comparison to neurotypical people. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 24, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'We might find it hard to switch from awake to asleep, the same way we find it hard to change tasks, resulting in inconsistent bedtimes and sleep schedules. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 24, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Some of the things we may experience: Increased brain activity may make it harder for us to relax, eventually leading to insomnia. Sensory sensitivities to lights and sounds might be too distracting, keeping us awake. Daytime exhaustion might force us to take long naps in the afternoon to get through the day, which could alter our sleep at night. Night wakings and night anxiety. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 24, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Sensory differences can play a huge role in our sleeping patterns too. Room temperature, clothes, pillows, blankets, light sound -for for many of us, finding the "perfect" conditions to fall asleep is not easy. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 24, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Furthermore, coexistent conditions, such as anxiety and ADHD, can make things even more challenging as they are known to cause sleep problems as well. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 24, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Lack of sleep or inadequate sleep quality can result in: Lower tolerance threshold -we may be more likely to be dysregulated or sensory overloaded. Difficulty with focus, memory, organizing, and other executive skills. •Physical discomfort headaches, exhaustion, fatigue during the day. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 24, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Some things that might help you: •Decrease Decrease brain stimulation as your bedtime gets closer; reading a book coloring, or journaling are great ways to tone it down. •Make your bedroom more comfortable. Be aware of noises, lights, textures. Even what you wear to sleep, if uncomfortable, can make it harder for you to fall asleep. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 24, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Some things that might help you: A warm bath or stretching, if possible, might help you wind down before bedtime. Do your best to go to bed and wake up at the same time every day. Keeping a routine can help your brain automatically set fixed hours of sleep, increasing the likelihood of staying asleep throughout the night. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 24, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'I use Tiimo (@tiimoapp) to remind me when it's bedtime so can go to bed at the same time every day. Not having a sleep routine massively impacts my executive functioning, sensory processing and emotiona regulation. 23:00 Bedtime Sleep well 23:15 To learn more: @tiimoapp or visit tiimoapp.com'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 22, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'As an Autistic person, changes are difficult for me because they create so much uncertainty. @theautisticlife'.

node.text:
Can you relate to this? I know this is not the case for many Autistic people so please don’t consider this as a fixed trait. It’s not. My need for sameness comes from a need to feel safe. I’m not trying to come off as controlling for the sake of it. It’s not a matter of “you just want it your way.” I know it may seem like that, but all I’m doing is trying to be comfortable and make sure these things I want to do don’t end up leading me to a meltdown, shutdown or sensory overload. In my latest podcast episode I talk about this topic in more depth, from my understanding of things and my own personal experience, in case you want to check it out 💛 @theautisticlifepodcast is available on Spotify, Apple Podcasts and Google Podcasts.
.
.
.
#autism #autistic #actuallyautistic #autisticadults #autisticteens #autismo #autista #mujeresautistas #aspie #aspiegirl #aspergers #aspergerssyndrome #aspergerslife #neurodiversity #neurodiverse #neurodivergent  #autismmoms #autismdads #autismparents #autismmomsrock #autisticselfadvocacy #autismpride #redinstead #autismrights

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Autistic Life on May 22, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'As an Autistic person, changes are difficult for me because they create so much uncertainty. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 22, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Familiar places, people, foods, clothes, these mean a familiar level of stress that I already know I can handle without many consequences. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 22, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Changes unfold a whole new array of possibilities. While some of them might be good, others may not, and knowing what happens next can help us avoid a lot of stress. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 22, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'To many of us, our need for sameness comes from doing damage contro and ensuring, as best possible, our sensory, emotional, and physical safety. @theautisticlife'.
Photo by The Autistic Life on May 03, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Meltdowns are not a result of "being Autistic." @theautisticlife'.

node.text:
Does this resonate with you? Have you ever been told you were “overreacting” after experiencing a meltdown? I can’t help but think of a few years back, when my ex partner used to push my buttons to the point of a meltdown and then say “OMG LOOK HOW MUCH YOU ARE OVERREACTING! SUCH A DRAMA QUEEN!” but what happened before that? What happened before the meltdown? There were hours and hours of painful sensory input, debilitating stress and hypervigilant anxiety. I used to feel so much shame whenever I experienced a meltdown but these days… not so much. I understand this built-up has to leave my body. I understand I’ve been tolerating things for far too long, sometimes things I’m not even aware of, until too on edge to recognize I’m two steps away from a meltdown. We have to stop shaming ourselves, and we have to stop shaming Autistic people for experiencing a meltdown. Yes, they are NOT pretty to “deal with” if you are a parent/parent/caregiver/sibbling, but they are incredibly SCARY to experience. The last thing we need is someone telling us we are overreacting.
.
.
.
#autism #autistic #actuallyautistic #autisticadults #autisticteens #autismo #autista #mujeresautistas #aspie #aspiegirl #aspergers #aspergerssyndrome #aspergerslife #neurodiversity #neurodiverse #neurodivergent  #autismmoms #autismdads #autismparents #autismmomsrock #autisticselfadvocacy #autismpride #redinstead #autismrights

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Autistic Life on May 03, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Meltdowns are not a result of "being Autistic." @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 03, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Meltdowns are the final stage of a much longer process consisting of silently, and sometimes unconsciously, tolerating high levels of stress and anxiety for too long. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 03, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'While meltdowns may seem out of context or disproportionate to the situation, it's essential to consider how much the Autistic person has quietly endured before reaching the point of a meltdown. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 03, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Prolonged exposure to a demanding, uncomfortable, environment, with limited opportunity to reduce or regulate stimuli, means at some point our coping mechanisms are completely overwhelmed. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 03, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Don't make assumptions about an Autistic person experiencing a meltdown or dismiss them, saying they are "overreacting." @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on May 03, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Behind every intense externalization such as a meltdown, there are unbearable levels of anxiety and distress that lead us there in the first place. @theautisticlife'.
Photo by The Autistic Life on April 30, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'The importance of sensory breaks. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

node.text:
Do you take sensory breaks? What are your favorite ways of taking a sensory break? Thank you so much to @tiimoapp for collaborating with me to bring you this post 💛 sensory breaks are something I’ve been implementing this past month where I’ve been struggling with Autistic burnout, and it’s made quite the difference! I’ve noticed fewer sensory overloads, therefore, less shutdowns simply by stopping every now and then to check in with my body and sensory needs. It sounds too simple to cause so many changes, but it genuinely helps 💛
.
.
.
#autism #autistic #actuallyautistic #autisticadults #autisticteens #autismo #autista #mujeresautistas #aspie #aspiegirl #aspergers #aspergerssyndrome #aspergerslife #neurodiversity #neurodiverse #neurodivergent  #autismmoms #autismdads #autismparents #autismmomsrock #autisticselfadvocacy #autismpride #redinstead #autismrights

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Autistic Life on April 30, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'The importance of sensory breaks. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Sensory breaks are intentional moments of our day when we allow ourselves to regulate our systems after being exposed to disorganized stimuli for a period of time. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 30, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Our differences in sensory processing mean that we are often at risk of experiencing sensory overload simply by interacting with our environment. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Furthermore, due to interoception challenges, we don't always know we are sensory uncomfortable until we are already significantly overloaded. By then, it is difficult to do something about it. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Sensory breaks will look different from one Autistic person to another as they will depend on your individual sensory needs and sensory profile. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Some sensory break ideas include: Sitting in a room with dimmed lights or curtains closed to reduce visual input. .Stretching and sitting in comfortable positions to provide proprioceptive input. Using stim toys or stim-dancing. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Some sensory break ideas include: •Opting for crunchy snacks or snacks with your preferred texture and taste. .Lighting up a scented candle or incense with a pleasant smell. .Jumping, running, skipping. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Some sensory break ideas include: .Watching something calming, such as looking at a tree out of the window. .Listening to loud music for controlled auditory input, or using noise-canceling headphones to reduce auditory input. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Controlled sensory input allows our systems to reorganize the sensory information we are receiving in a way that feels comfortable and safe for our brains. @theautisticlife @tiimoapp'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'make I use Tiimo to create my routines, and sure to add this activity throughout my day to check in with my body and allow my system to take a break and regulate when need to. 14:00 Sensory break Take a moment to regulate 14:30 To learn more: @tiimoapp or visit tiimoapp.com'.
Photo by The Autistic Life on April 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Autistic people and the need to sit in unusual positions. @theautisticlife'.

node.text:
Can you relate? Hi, sitting still is weird and makes me so uncomfortable. If other things are happening and stressing me out, sitting with both of my feet on the ground makes me want to scream and cry because it's literally too painful. I wish it wasn't considered "weird" or "unprofessional" to sit on the floor or in similar positions since it helps many of us to feel comfortable and present in whatever we are engaging with. 
.
.
.
#autism #autistic #actuallyautistic #autisticadults #autisticteens #autismo #autista #mujeresautistas #aspie #aspiegirl #aspergers #aspergerssyndrome #aspergerslife #neurodiversity #neurodiverse #neurodivergent #autismmoms #autismdads #autismparents #autismmomsrock #autisticselfadvocacy #autismpride #redinstead #autismrights

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Autistic Life on April 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Autistic people and the need to sit in unusual positions. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Proprioception is the sense that provides information to our brains about where our body is in space. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Autistic people often have proprioceptive differences due to our sensory processing systems and, as a result, may have a hard time sitting still or in "typical" ways. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'For many many of us, sitting with both feet on the ground or arms resting on the sides mean that our brains are not receiving enough proprioceptive input, resulting in feeling uncomfortable and disconnected from our bodies. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'This can manifest as: •Sitting cross-le legged, even on chairs. •Sitting with your knees to your chest, hugging your shins with your arm. •Sitting on your feet or ankles. Leaning your head on your hand. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'This can manifest as: •Resting your chin in your hand •Putting your elbows on the table. .Switching from one position to another fairly quickly. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'I prefer sitting cross-legged on the floor or a couch with my leg beneath me. I can tolerate regular chairs for some time, especially if I can sit sideways or on my foot. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'But context matters. Sitting still in a place where there's overwhelming sensory stimulus around me makes sitting "properly" genuinely distressing and painful. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'This constant shifting gives our brains proprioceptive feedback allowing us to focus more, feel more organized, and integrate ourselves with our environment. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'MORE CONTENT ON PATREON If you like my work and is accessobl for you to do so, please consider supporting my Patreon to get more resources and to show extra love! THE AUTISTIC LIFE 8 The Autistic Life is creating resources on autism, neurodivergence and mental health PATREON LINK IN BIO'.
Photo by The Autistic Life on April 05, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'As an Autistic person, I dread upcoming events. @theautisticlife'.

node.text:
Can you relate? What does it usually help you? The word “dread” doesn’t even begin to describe how much I hate upcoming events. Even if they are positive events that I actually look forward to, the amount of mental preparation required from me is so much to the point that I can’t think of anything else other than the upcoming event, sometimes if I’m days away from happening. 
.
.
.
#autism #autistic #actuallyautistic #autisticadults #autisticteens #autismo #autista #mujeresautistas #aspie #aspiegirl #aspergers #aspergerssyndrome #aspergerslife #neurodiversity #neurodiverse #neurodivergent  #autismmoms #autismdads #autismparents #autismmomsrock #autisticselfadvocacy #autismpride #redinstead #autismrights

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Autistic Life on April 05, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'As an Autistic person, I dread upcoming events. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Many of us us may start to worry about the amount of effort we'll have to put into getting through the event, sometimes weeks before it happens. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The sensory hell it might be, all the nonverbal social cues we must remember, keeping up with conversations, being aware of your body language, the routine disruption. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 05, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'We know how much of an emotionally exhausting day will be before it happens and it can cause so much anxiety. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Sometimes we might get stuck on it, unable to do anything else because we have this one thing scheduled taking up all of our mental energy. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'We can't bring ourselves to do anything else because switching our attention from one task to another, especially when the requires so much of us, can be incredibly challenging. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'What helps me: Knowing as many many details as possible about the even to lessen lessen the likelihood of unexpected and stressful situations. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'What helps me: Mentally prepare myself for all potential scenarios, both good bot and bad, to develop possible coping strategies to those unexpected challenges. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'What helps me: Reminding myself through positive self-talk that I've gone through these terribly anxiety anxiety-inducing situations before, and I've overcome them. @theautisticlife'.

Photo by The Autistic Life on April 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'What helps me: Preparing a de-escalation plan after the event has passed to lower my anxiety levels, such as as resting or engaging in special interests. @theautisticlife'.
